Not really. That was a mistake on his part, definitely, but not too serious. Tokyo is an absolutely massive area so he could still feasibly avoid detection.

If Light had have just been patient and calmed down, he would have been basically completely cleared.

How did it address this? Everything else is about the police and their failures. We don't get to see the community's reaction. It's a really artificial portrayal of what that kind of unsolved murders does to everyone around. It's almost like the community is in the background. There are crowds of people around a murder scene but they're passive observers resigned to let it continue happening. Incompetent police is active, bereaved community is passive. I don't know if it's irony in bad taste or just bad writing.

How are you filtered this badly? The entire point was that the police were negligent of the community. The people in the town were very poor, they were increasingly being used for industrial labor, their living conditions were awful, the police brutalized student protesters, and residents with disabilities were mocked and humiliated. It’s in the background because the whole scheme of the film is showing the obsession of the cops with the murder case at the expense of the normal people whom they have no connection with. That’s why it ends with the detective realizing that the killer was an ordinary person instead of a criminal mastermind. He blended in with the community that they disregarded and that’s why they never found the killer. He looks at the audience because we’re the normal people and the killer still blends in with the average crowd watching the film.

>Die Feuerzangenbowle
It's a very traditional german comedy with one of the greatest actors we had. It plays every christmas. It's about a professor who is having some bowle with his colleagues who are talking about the fun times they had during school. When they figure out that Dr. Pfeiffer (Heinz Rühmann) really did not have any of those experiences since he was homeschooled they decide in a drunk state to make him appear as a young guy and send him to school for some time to make his experiences. It's a beautiful movie. The english name is The Punch Bowl. "Es geschah am hellichten Tag" is a crime movie mixed with some comedy about a child murder and "Quax der Bruchpilot" is another comedy about a guy who wins to make a license as a pilot. It plays in bavaria. All three of them are with Heinz Rühmann.

Don't go in expecting excitement. It's a very slow and deliberate movie, but I love it for capturing the eighteenth century ambition for machinelike discipline and order while telling a very emotional story centered around the most basic human emotions of love and vengeance.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>179796736
>>179797237
Blue Spring is awesome, just watched it a few months ago. As far as angry politics in movies go I don't think you can beat the Japanese New Wave, the political and formal radicalism of that period still hasn't been matched since, imo its the high point of the medium so far. I'd recommend going through Oshima's run from the sixties to early seventies as a whole but I have to say that his film The Ceremony is right up there with the most bitter and angry movies about politics and generational conflict (specifically between the WWII generation and their children) ever, its not as bombastic as Throw Away Your Books but far more cutting about the state of Japan. It honestly deserves the same degree of attention as Hara-Kiri, High and Low, etc.

>>179788973
In Resident Evil: Extinction, the Nevada facility has an underground copy of part of the Mansion, part of the Hive, and part of the Raccoon City hospital. They were trying to get their inferior Alice clones to work properly by having them go through the traumatic experiences the main one did.

In Final Chapter, they return to the nuked ruins of Raccoon City, to the OG Hive from the first movie. It is revealed that the Hive is actually hiding an elevator that leads down to another complex where the REAL Umbrella execs are in storage awaiting the end of the world and the rebirth in its glorious ashes or whatever.

Down there she meets the REAL Dr. Isaacs. He is the head of Umbrella. Wesker is his lackey who pretends he doesn't know what is really going on, but is actually aware of Umbrella's real plan, which was to leave Umbrella in the hands of clones, and let the apocalypse play out, and wait for everything to settle down. So the Umbrella execs in Extinction (film 3) are just clones who don't know any better. They don't know they were set up to fail.

And meanwhile the real Umbrella heads, when they wake up, are bemused to see that Alice is still alive because Alice was just a one off thing. A programmed clone that was designed to help the virus escape from the Hive. She was meant to die in the outbreak. But instead she kept going and has completely fucked everything they'd planned.

It's all rather complicated, and they REALLY should have done a better job explaining it in the opening monologues. (Also, some of it was clearly last minute retcons. Originally, Alicia Marcus was meant to be the real head of Umbrella, not Isaacs. The original plan for Isaacs was that he would be her son, and actually a really kind man who'd been trying to fix the situation the whole time, with Alice being shocked to discover that he was nothing like the clone versions she'd met. That was all scrapped and as a result it's all kind of spit and glue.)

>>179787809
>You see the shaky cam and 50+ cuts in this 30 second clip creates a feeling of nausea and pain in the audience which is exactly what the heroine is feeling
Believe it or not, that was actually the idea. The editor wanted the entire film, start to finish, to be a breathless chase film. And sometimes Anderson would pop in and say, "Can you move that stuff closer together", meaning "can you cut this faster so the actions happen quicker", and the editor obliged. The problem is that this is a terrible idea for a 2 hour movie. Every scene in the movie is edited really, really fast. Talking is edited fast. A lot of normal talking shots are 1.1 seconds long for no particular reason than "This helps us feel empathy for Alice's desperation and pain".

>>179789893
>Was Isaacs brought back because he was a Game of Thrones actor?
That was definitely a factor, yes. But another factor was that Wesker and Alice never actually had any real relationship. Originally Isaacs was going to appear in the film in a small role. As Alicia's son. But when things starting going weird with production he was upgraded to main villain playing two different versions of the same character. One, a religious zealot. The other, a cold, calculating executive.

Originally, all the actors from Retribution were going to come back. I wish that had happened. I wish they'd shot the movie in 3D so we would have gotten really stable camera work like Retribution. There's so much coulda woulda shoulda with how the RE series ended. I'm sure that they're happy they got to tell the end of the story. No eternal cliffhanger. But at this point, if they make another Resident Evil movie with Milla coming back, there's almost a 50% chance they'll just retcon Final Chapter and make a sequel to Retribution. It might sound like a joke, but THAT would sell. That would be the nostalgia bait "Remember that epic showdown you were promised? Here it is! Here's the do-over!"

>>179793251
Constantin Werner is a German indie filmmaker, with his most notable film being a dark drama called Dead Leaves:
https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0308153/?ref_=nm_knf_t_3
Several years ago he purchased the rights to three short stories from GRRM. Bitterblooms, In the Lost Lands, and one other one.

He planned to adapt these into a single film, and he cast Milla Jovovich as Gray Alys. This was in 2015. However, nothing came of this, and it wasn't until 2021 when the project re-emerged, with Paul W.S. Anderson stepping in to direct, and Constantin Werner co-writing and producing. The other stories had been discarded and they were only adapting In the Lost Lands now.

What I believe has happened is that Constantin couldn't get funding for the project. asking people for like 50 million dollars is really hard. But you know who can ask people for 50 million dollars? Paul W.S. Anderson. And they already have Milla Jovovich attached? Even better. Just replace Justin Chatwin with Dave Bautista, and we're off.

Paul has always wanted to direct a western (Soldier was the closest he came) and he's basically envisioning this adaptation as a sort of fantasy/western/post-apocalyptic hybrid thing.

In 1998 they were then involved in a pay dispute in which Fox threatened to replace them with new actors and went as far as preparing for casting of new voices. However, the issue was soon resolved and from 1998 to 2004, they were paid $125,000 per episode. In 2004, the voice actors intentionally skipped several table reads, demanding they be paid $360,000 per episode.[15] The strike was resolved a month later[16] and until 2008 they earned something between $250,000[17] and $360,000 per episode.[18] In 2008, production for the twentieth season was put on hold due to new contract negotiations with the voice actors, who wanted a "healthy bump" in salary to an amount close to $500,000 per episode.[18] The dispute was soon resolved, and the actors' salary was raised to $400,000 per episode.[19]

>>179786933
Because he slid into the hole head and torso first with the front of his legs sliding along the lower part of the passage, then as he slipped further and further down his feet became elevated, getting close to the top of the passage before he slid straight down to his ankles. The only way out of that kind of geometry is by lifting his feet straight up toward the ceiling until the portion of his legs below the constriction is short enough that there's space for his butt to move away from the rescuer, and his feet to move toward him, then he could be conventionally pulled from that point on. If the last pulley was located where the rescuer was the vertical component of force from a pull would be insufficient to overcome the friction of his legs against the constriction. They could pull as hard as they wanted but he'd never come out. At best they'd break his shins and end up with a pair of dismembered feet or feet and part of his legs tied to a rope at the surface.

>>179788787
The trio are teens and so the tone has matured. It's genuinely scary at times. Harry decisively gets the fuck out of the Dursley's at the beginning, the mark of a man.

The otherworldly quality of the dementors adds a lot of intrigue to both the film and series as a whole. Lupin's introduction is spellbinding. Harry's first encounter with the dementors at the lake is terrifying. That same encounter replayed later is unsettling still, terrifying even, but cathartic.
Finally the reveal that Sirius is a good guy was well played. Rowling has a penchant for mystery and this was probably the best mystery tale of the series.

There was a gravitas in this film that was absent from the first two. The decision to have plain clothes added tons of realism which raised the stakes, emotionally.

Also their hair looked fantastic across the board.

In short, great direction and a bold new tone really bolstered this entry in the franchise. The series peaked with this film and GoF.
Shitshow from there on out. That said the best film is still the first.
